page.title: 17HISTORY IN BASSINGBOURN
page.content: The road that runs past Bassingbourn is called Ermine Street. It was built by the Romans around 60 A.D. Another old road called Ashwell Street runs on the southern boundary of the village. There is the site of a castle in one of our areas. A man called Sir Warin de Bassingbourn used to live in the castle at around 1266. It was later owned by John of Gaunt. Now you can only see the shadow of the foundations from the air. The Earls of Richmond owned the manor from 1066. Lady Margaret Beaufort was the mother of Henry Tudor (Henry VII). There is a Tudor tithe barn at Manor Farm. In 1511 the villagers performed a play about St George and the dragon on St Margaret's day (July 20th). There are lots of books in the County Library, Cambridgeshire Collection, by local people about Bassingbourn.
